review.title: Transfer Learning Using Logistic Regression in Credit Scoring
review.abstract: The credit scoring risk management is a fast growing field due to consumer's credit requests. Credit requests, of new and existing customers, are often evaluated by classical discrimination rules based on customers information. However, these kinds of strategies have serious limits and don't take into account the characteristics difference between current customers and the future ones. The aim of this paper is to measure credit worthiness for non customers borrowers and to model potential risk given a heterogeneous population formed by borrowers customers of the bank and others who are not. We hold on previous works done in generalized gaussian discrimination and transpose them into the logistic model to bring out efficient discrimination rules for non customers' subpopulation.

sections.heading: 4.1 Credit Data Set and Subpopulations Definition
sections.text: The data set adopted here is a real word set: German credit data, illustrated in Figure 1, available in the UCI Machine Learning Repository (http: / / archive.ics.uci.edu / ml / datasets.html) or see also (Fahrmeir and Tutz, 1994) for further descriptions. The data set is often used by credit specialists. It covers a sample of 1000 credit consumers, 700 of whom are creditworthy and 300 not. Each applicant is described by a binary target variable credit, credit = 1 for creditworthy and credit = 0, otherwise 20 other input variables are assumed to affect this target variable, maturity of loans in months (maturity), repayment of other loans (morals), value of savings or shares (savings account), stability in employment (occupation), other current loans (Weitkred).

sections.heading: 5 Conclusion
sections.text: We have proposed seven simple logistic submodels that combine the classification rule for the customer subpopulation with the marked sample from the non-customer subpopulation. A comparison of the performance of the seven models was performed and the models M3 and M4 were selected as the best classification model for the non-customer subpopulation; these two models suggest the performance of the traditional classification model M1. This research could have yielded more interesting results if we had been able to have a sample of a larger size. We envisage as a perspective the application of logistic regression using non-linear links between the two subpopulations. We can also apply a non-parametric approach that can appear efficient once the linear models find their limits.

metadata.abstractText: The credit scoring risk management is a fast growing field due to consumer’s credit requests. Credit requests, of new and existing customers, are often evaluated by classical discrimination rules based on customers information. However, these kinds of strategies have serious limits and don’t take into account the characteristics difference between current customers and the future ones. The aim of this paper is to measure credit worthiness for non customers borrowers and to model potential risk given a heterogeneous population formed by borrowers customers of the bank and others who are not. We hold on previous works done in generalized gaussian discrimination and transpose them into the logistic model to bring out efficient discrimination rules for non customers’ subpopulation. Therefore we obtain several simple models of connection between parameters of both logistic models associated respectively to the two subpopulations. The German credit data set is selected to experiment and to compare these models. Experimental results show that the use of links between the two subpopulations improve the classification accuracy for the new loan applicants.
